ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I will recommend ENAS 642 01 to another student. The course is relevant and important. The professor teaches well and the test are fair.

We are provided with a foundation in chemical reaction engineering - at first, these seem extraneous to the overall course objective, but then we tie back some concepts later on with chemical reaction engineering processes, which was a very nice trajectory. The stepwise discussion of different small-scale, mechanistic aspects of water and wastewater treatment processes was excellent. This added nicely to the practical, process-based teaching I had from my undergraduate studies at another institution. This is a required course for environmental engineers, but I would recommend to students even if it wasn't because of the professor's excellence and the overall utility of the course content in environmental engineering.

Provided a knowledgeable overview regarding various environmental applicable processes. I would recommend this course to another student who is interested in environmental engineering as it provides a great introductory overview.
Helpful for membrane and chemical engineering reactor work. Would recommend for those goals.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: The course is not dependent on previous knowledge and it is contribute to my research.

The discussion of the mechanisms of different physical/chemical phenomena were extremely valuable. It may have a good contribution to my dissertation depending on the direction that it goes in the coming years.
